Problem:
Consider a physical system where the displacement \\( x(t) \\) of a particle is governed by the differential equation \\( \\ddot{x} = -kx \\), typically representing a harmonic oscillator. We study the effect of a Fourier transform applied to the initial velocity condition \\( v_0 \\) and its impact over time.

If the initial velocity \\( v_0 \\) is transformed by a Fourier transform \\( F(v_0) \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\ddot{x} = -kx \\) without further intervention, will the displacement \\( x(t) \\) at time t be the same as if the original \\( v_0 \\) was used?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of the initial velocity \\( v_0 \\) alters the frequency components of the system's initial state, potentially impacting how the displacement evolves over time according to the system equation. Variations in these components due to the transform will result in a different displacement \\( x(t) \\).
